Subject: Concerns relating to Mr. Algernon Yau, CEO of Cathay Dragon & Director of Service Delivery, Cathay Pacific

Dear Sir/Madam,

We write to express our concern over dehumanising remarks made by Mr. Algernon Yau, CEO of Cathay Dragon & Director of Service Delivery, Cathay Pacific, through his social media account, which is indicative of the above mentioned position.

On 17 July 2019, Mr. Yau re-shared a post from a Facebook page called “支持香港警察“ (“Supporting the Hong Kong Police”) on his social media account. For the screenshot of the post on Mr. Yau’s Facebook account, see footnote 1 below. The relevant Facebook post stated in Chinese, among other things, that ”Last night, two cockroaches legislators hid inside the toilet cubicles in a shopping mall to avoid being confronted by Yuen Long residents”. Mr. Yau’s Facebook post was widely reported by the media. For copies of the relevant news reports, please see footnotes 2 and 3 below.

By describing certain legislators as cockroaches, one cannot help but associate Mr. Yau’s Facebook post with remarks made by Leon Mugesera, a former Rwanda politician who described Tutsis as ""cockroaches"" and called for their extermination in the 1994 Rwanda genocide. Mr. Yau’s endorsement of the depiction that certain legislators are cockroaches appears to have violated Swire Pacific’s Human Rights Policy which emphasises the importance of creating an inclusive and supportive working environment for all its employees regardless of their political beliefs. The said policy also expressly provides that discrimination or harassment based on the foregoing is not tolerated.

It has been widely reported that Cathay Pacific and Cathay Dragon recently revised its Code of Conduct to make clear that “activities which may bring the Company into disrepute, impact an employee’s ability to carry out their duties or impair the Company’s ability to meet any applicable legal or regulatory requirements, may attract disciplinary consequences including termination of employment”. It is regrettable and entirely unaccepable that Cathay Dragon’s CEO endorses depictions used in a genocide, which by all standards is dehumanising. I believe that Mr. Yau’s endorsement of the depiction that certain legislators are cockroaches has brought Cathay Dragon into disrepute.

In addition, “thug” and “cockroach”, this is entirely out of my anticipation that such hate speech is used by a senior leader in an international airline, who is responsible and accountable for aviation safety, as well as to harmonise the airline and the aviation community. Undoubtedly, this kind of expression can never alleviate the current difficulties in the society whereas aggravate the social tensions, both in HongKong and other countries.

In view of Mr. Yau’s Facebook post, I have grave concerns as to whether Mr. Yau is suited to continue to lead Cathay Dragon & Cathay Pacific, and I trust you will take appropriate action to address the public’s concern accordingly.

Yours faithfully,

Footnote
